Award.AwardTitle: Neuronal Reorganization Underlies Evolution of Novel Adaptive Behavior
Award.AbstractNarration:
The taste system detects and discriminates among tastants that convey information about the quality and nutritional value of food. In response to selection with insecticide baits that contain sugars, populations of the German cockroach have become averse to glucose and fructose. This emergent trait is genetically-encoded and it provides a huge advantage to the cockroach when glucose- or fructose-containing baits are used in pest control. The German cockroach is a world-wide pest with significant economic and medical impacts on society. It is a principal source of allergens that can trigger asthma and vector of pathogenic microorganisms, including antibiotic resistant strains. This project will delineate the mechanisms responsible for the rapid emergence of this novel behavior with behavioral, electrophysiological and genetic analyses. This research is the first in any animal to (a) characterize rapid changes in the taste system that have resulted in the emergence of a new adaptive behavior; (b) describe in detail a novel sensory mechanism where a single stimulus at the same intensity drives opposite acceptance and rejection responses by activating different taste neurons; and (c) characterize the best understood case of behavioral resistance in animals. Although behavioral resistance is often cited as a major impediment to efficacious pest control, the mechanisms that underlie behavioral resistance are not known. This research represents the clearest explanation of sensory mechanisms that underlie the rapid emergence of a behavioral resistance trait in animal populations. The findings are being incorporated into several textbooks and apps on Neurobiology, Behavior and Evolution.

Taste polymorphisms are often described as changes in sensitivity of gustatory receptor neurons (GRNs) within a taste modality, with phenotypes ranging from highly sensitive to completely insensitive to a particular compound. The proposed project addresses a unique gain-of-function natural polymorphism that results in a highly adaptive behavior. The project will test the hypotheses that (a) glucose and fructose are processed as deterrents by GRNs, (b) different taste organs differ in their GRN organization, contributing to effective processing of tastants as appetitive and aversive stimuli, and (c) that the molecular mechanism(s) that underlie this neuronal change involves either mis-expression of sugar-gustatory receptors (GRs) on bitter GRNs or modifications of bitter-GRs on bitter-GRNs for affinity for glucose or fructose. Approaches and methods will include behavioral observations of tastant acceptance and rejection, electrophysiological studies using a single sensillum preparation, morphological studies using light, scanning and confocal microscopy, and genetic studies with artificially selected lineages of cockroaches. Genetic resources include 20 lines of selection-with-recurrent-backcrossing at each generation for avoidance of specific sugars, as well as lines in which these traits have been introgressed into a closely related species. Annotation of all chemoreceptors in the genome sequence will be followed by a Pool-seq approach, whole-genome re-sequencing and RNA-seq. Understanding the gustatory system of cockroaches, a primitive hemimetabolous lineage, will contribute to a broader understanding of insect gustation that so far has centered mainly on holometabolous and more highly advanced Diptera and Hymenoptera.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

The taste system detects and discriminates tastants that convey information about the quality of food. In response to selection with insecticide baits that contain sugars, populations of the German cockroach, Blattella germanica, have become averse to glucose and fructose. These emergent traits are genetically encoded and provide a huge advantage to the cockroach when glucose- or fructose-containing baits are used in pest control. The overall goal of the project was to delineate the mechanisms responsible for the rapid emergence of this novel behavior with behavioral, electrophysiological and genetic analyses.

Electrophysiological experiments using glucose- and fructose-averse cockroaches showed that the basis of their avoidance behavior is that glucose and fructose stimulate bitter-responsive taste cells and thus drive aversion behavior. However, topographic mapping of the distribution of taste sensilla showed that the organization of the taste system is conserved in sugar-loving and sugar-aversive cockroaches and the projections of taste cells to the central nervous system (brain) is also conserved. These results support the idea that the sugar-aversion trait is based in changes in taste cells and not in how they connect to the brain. We generated multiple genetic lines of sugar-averse cockroaches and also transferred this trait into a related Blattella species. In collaboration with the i5k arthropod genomics initiative, we sequenced the genome of this cockroach and annotated all its chemosensory genes. We discovered that this cockroach has the largest chemoreceptor repertoire of any insect or other arthropod examined to date, in keeping with its remarkably wide dietary range. We identified candidate sugar receptors from the genome sequence, documented their expression in various taste organs, and genetically suppressed their expression to identify genes responsible for sugar-aversion.

A fascinating discovery was that saliva enzymes can extend the glucose-aversion phenotype: While normal cockroaches that accepted glucose satiate on more complex sugars (complex saccharides, like maltose and matotriose), glucose-averse cockroaches ceased ingesting these sugars within seconds, resulting in significantly lower consumption. By mixing cockroach saliva with various sugars, we demonstrated that saliva breaks down oligosaccharides into glucose, which drives glucose-aversion in cockroaches. Acarbose, an inhibitor of this breakdown process, prevented the accumulation of glucose and retained the stimulatory response and ingestion of oligosaccharides. These findings suggest that the genetic mechanism of glucose-aversion supports an extended sugar-aversion phenotype that includes all glucose-containing oligosaccharides. Finally, we found that this trait interferes with sexual behavior. Sugars are important components of the male?s nuptial courtship offering to the female. We found that glucose-averse females reject courting males because her saliva distorts the taste quality of the sugary gift. Interestingly, glucose-averse males have modified the composition of their nuptial gift to match the perception and preferences of glucose-averse females.

 

A major impact on the discipline is showing that major genes can regulate behavior. The unique sugar-aversions we found in multiple populations of the German cockroach show that shifts in food preferences are accompanied by changes in the peripheral chemosensory system, and this is one of the best examples of rapid evolution of adaptive behavioral traits. It is also an excellent example of behavioral resistance ? an adaptive behavioral trait that either diminishes an insect?s exposure to toxic compounds or allows it to survive in what would otherwise be a toxic and lethal environment.

Broader impacts:

Mentoring: Schal and Robertson mentored 5 undergraduate students, 3 graduate students, 2 postdoctoral researchers, 2 research technicians and 4 visiting scientists. Four high school students conducted independent research projects.

Outreach: All personnel on the project conducted many outreach and community engagement activities, including hands-on sessions for elementary school classes, and an annual BugFest event that draws 35,000 people. We organized exhibits in the annual Brain Awareness Day at the NC Museum of Natural Sciences. Our outreach presentations have reached thousands of people including K-12, adults, the pest control industry, affordable housing residents and management, HUD personnel, and the general public.

Products: We published 38 peer-reviewed publications, some of which were extensively covered in the media (for example, 3 genome-related papers). Several books had significant coverage of sugar-aversion as an example of rapid evolution in the anthropogenic environment. We presented findings of this project in 50 professional presentations and 24 outreach events that reached thousands of participants. Face-to-face activities have been limited since mid-March 2020, but outreach, mentoring, project discussions, and professional development activities continued on virtual platforms.

Broader impacts: The German cockroach is a worldwide pest with significant economic and medical impacts on society. It is a principal source of indoor allergens that can trigger asthma and it vectors pathogenic microorganisms, including antibiotic resistant bacteria. The sugar aversion behaviors that we investigate guide the development of better baits for control of cockroach infestations.
